articles.headline: Gunman in Jerusalem Attack Identified
articles.snippet: The gunman who entered a prominent Jewish seminary and killed at least eight students was named by police as Ala Abu Dhaim.
articles.abstract: The gunman who entered a prominent Jewish seminary and killed at least eight students was named by police as Ala Abu Dhaim.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  The families of the eight students who were killed by a gunman at a prominent Jewish seminary in Jerusalem on Thursday night buried their dead on Friday as the Israeli authorities tightened security around the city.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Party Donations Show G.O.P. Edge
articles.snippet: For all the money raised by the Democratic presidential candidates, the Republicans are beating them in one crucial area: fund-raising by the parties themselves.
articles.abstract: For all the money raised by the Democratic presidential candidates, the Republicans are beating them in one crucial area: fund-raising by the parties themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For all the success that Democratic presidential candidates have had in raising money  taking in a combined total of over $500 million in the current race  the Republicans are beating them in one crucial area of fund-raising: the money being raised by the parties themselves.

articles.headline: Aversion to Risk Deepens Credit Woes
articles.snippet: Investors sought absolute safety, even moving away from debt issued by two government-sponsored mortgage lending enterprises.
articles.abstract: Investors sought absolute safety, even moving away from debt issued by two government-sponsored mortgage lending enterprises.
articles.lead_paragraph: The credit markets came under renewed stress Thursday as investors sought absolute safety and even moved away from debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage lending enterprises.

articles.headline: Senate Votes to Strengthen Product Safety Laws
articles.snippet: The legislation would create a public database of complaints about products and empower state prosecutors to take action to protect consumers.
articles.abstract: The legislation would create a public database of complaints about products and empower state prosecutors to take action to protect consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Responding to a wave of defective toys and other goods, the Senate approved a measure on Thursday to overhaul the country’s consumer product laws and strengthen the beleaguered safety agency that oversees the marketplace.

articles.headline: F.A.A. Fines Southwest Air in Inspections
articles.snippet: The F.A.A. proposed a record penalty, $10.2 million, against Southwest Airlines on Thursday because, it said, the carrier had misled officials.
articles.abstract: The F.A.A. proposed a record penalty, $10.2 million, against Southwest Airlines on Thursday because, it said, the carrier had misled officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration proposed a record penalty, $10.2 million, against Southwest Airlines on Thursday because, it said, the carrier had misled officials about whether it kept flying older Boeing 737 planes for several days last year after failing to inspect them for cracks in the fuselage.

articles.headline: In California, a Generational Tale of Real Estate Boom and Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The story of the Dunmore family in California is the story of the nation’s housing crisis writ small, familial and mean.
articles.abstract: The story of the Dunmore family in California is the story of the nation’s housing crisis writ small, familial and mean.
articles.lead_paragraph: YUBA CITY, Calif.  When George P. Dunmore started his business in Sacramento in the early 1950s, World War II was over and the building boom was on. Over the next several decades his company, Dunmore Construction, along with other respected builders, took the tabula rasa that was California’s Central Valley and etched it with entire neighborhoods filled with well-built ranch houses on trim lawns.

articles.headline: As Foreclosures Rise, Investors Pull Back
articles.snippet: The figures are expected to increase pressure on policy makers and the mortgage industry to move faster to contain losses and help homeowners.
articles.abstract: The figures are expected to increase pressure on policy makers and the mortgage industry to move faster to contain losses and help homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Defaults on home mortgages touched another historic high late last year as foreclosures on adjustable-rate mortgages surged, an industry group reported on Thursday.

articles.headline: In Crisis, Zimbabwe Asks: Could Mugabe Lose?
articles.snippet: With an election approaching, Robert G. Mugabe is threatened by Zimbabwe’s misery — and by two rivals.
articles.abstract: With an election approaching, Robert G. Mugabe is threatened by Zimbabwe’s misery — and by two rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Robert G. Mugabe has run this country for so long that his presence is like some common particulate in the air, taken in with every breath. Gladys Sithole can barely recall a Zimbabwe without him, this inescapable “old man,” as she calls him, with godlike powers and all-too-human failings.

articles.headline: Loophole Lets Bank Rewrite the Calendar
articles.snippet: When Société Générale moved its $9.7 billion loss from 2008 — when it occurred — to 2007, it created a furor in accounting circles about whether standards can be evenly applied.
articles.abstract: When Société Générale moved its $9.7 billion loss from 2008 — when it occurred — to 2007, it created a furor in accounting circles about whether standards can be evenly applied.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not often that a major international bank admits it is violating well-established accounting rules, but that is what Société Générale has done in accounting for the fraud that caused the bank to lose 6.4 billion euros  now worth about $9.7 billion  in January.

articles.headline: Democrats Try to End Impasse Over Delegates
articles.snippet: The fate of the Florida and Michigan delegations has emerged as a battleground that could be as important to the candidates as April’s Pennsylvania primary.
articles.abstract: The fate of the Florida and Michigan delegations has emerged as a battleground that could be as important to the candidates as April’s Pennsylvania primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the two Democratic presidential candidates in near-deadlock and battling for every delegate, party leaders and the rival campaigns started searching in earnest on Thursday for a way to seat barred delegations from Florida and Michigan. But they remained deeply divided over how to do so.

articles.headline: Recreation Fees Rising in Wake of Fires’ Costs
articles.snippet: Federal land agencies are imposing new fees and increasing existing ones at recreation sites in the West.
articles.abstract: Federal land agencies are imposing new fees and increasing existing ones at recreation sites in the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMILTON, Mont.  Reeling from the high cost of fighting wildfires, federal land agencies have been imposing new fees and increasing existing ones at recreation sites across the West in an effort to raise tens of millions of dollars.
